flashcards.definition: The process by which green plants use sunlight to synthesize foods (glucose) from carbon dioxide and water, releasing oxygen as a byproduct.
A green pigment present in chloroplasts that absorbs light energy for photosynthesis. It absorbs red and blue light while reflecting green light.
An organelle found in plant cells where photosynthesis takes place. Contains chlorophyll and has two main regions: thylakoids and stroma.
Tiny pores on the surface of leaves that allow gas exchange. Carbon dioxide enters and oxygen exits through stomata during photosynthesis.
A simple sugar (C₆H₁₂O₆) produced during photosynthesis. Plants use it for energy and convert excess into starch for storage.
The first stage of photosynthesis that occurs in thylakoid membranes. Requires light energy to split water molecules, producing ATP, NADPH, and oxygen.
The light-independent reactions (dark reactions) of photosynthesis occurring in the stroma. Uses ATP and NADPH to convert CO₂ into glucose.
The process of converting inorganic carbon dioxide into organic compounds (glucose) during the Calvin cycle.
An organism that can produce its own food from simple inorganic substances. Plants are autotrophs because they perform photosynthesis.
An organism that cannot produce its own food and must consume other organisms. Animals and fungi are heterotrophs.
Membrane-bound compartments inside chloroplasts where light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis occur. Stacked thylakoids form grana.
The fluid-filled space surrounding thylakoids in chloroplasts where the Calvin cycle (light-independent reactions) occurs.
Adenosine triphosphate, the energy currency of cells. Produced during light-dependent reactions and used in the Calvin cycle.
A coenzyme that carries high-energy electrons produced during light-dependent reactions. Used to reduce CO₂ to glucose in the Calvin cycle.
The distance between successive peaks of a light wave. Different wavelengths correspond to different colors of light.
The range of all possible electromagnetic radiation. Visible light (400-700nm) is the portion used by plants for photosynthesis.
An environmental factor that restricts the rate of photosynthesis when in short supply. Examples: light intensity, CO₂ concentration, temperature.
The splitting of water molecules using light energy during the light-dependent reactions, releasing oxygen, protons, and electrons.
Organisms that produce organic compounds from inorganic substances through photosynthesis. They form the base of food chains.
The biogeochemical cycle by which carbon is exchanged among the biosphere, pedosphere, geosphere, hydrosphere, and atmosphere. Photosynthesis is a key process.
